Once again I have tried to find the wonderful doggerel tribute to the sainted MARGARET FARRAR that I remember from her retirement. I have found that it appeared in the Letters to the Editor of the Magazine, probably on January 26, 1969, and was written by Don Parks. Alas, the NYT archives won't let me see the text.

It began:

Hail, Margaret, Gretchen, Maggie, Meg!
Thou wast, or wert, a good old egg.
The ani in the upas tree
The ern upon the Azov Sea
Sing Ave and Adieu to thee.

It continues in that vein. There was something about:

The tribues of [something] and of Ute you
So frequently describe salute you.

I wish I could find the whole thing. But it apparently went POOF!

When Reagan became president the deficit was about 1 T.

Thus Reagan and the two Bushes added about 7.6 T to the deficit.
In his last years Clinton was running yearly surpluses.
Unfortunately Bush 43 dissipated that surplus with tax cuts for the rich.

To be fair (perhaps not to Republicans, who probably haven't thought about this at all, but to people who don't argue from definition): The position that deficit cuts are stimulative is not that by decreasing the deficit at time t, we thereby increase the private surplus at time t; but instead that by decreasing the deficit at time t, we increase the private surplus at time t+n, where n is a positive increment of time. However ill-advised, that position is not incoherent because of accounting identities, as you suggest.

However, what does follow from the accounting identity of public deficits and private savings is that there cannot be a positive rate of private savings if there is never a public deficit. Which means that it cannot be bad public policy to run a public deficit per se unless it's also bad public policy to encourage private savings.

"that mortality rates from cervical cancer in the U.S. are quite low"

Okay, maybe your kid won't actually die. They'll just have to undergo invasive and painful treatments (like surgery), maybe have their cervix or uterus removed and become infertile. Or have complications during pregnancy (as one commenter related above).

Who would want that for their daughter, if they could possibly avoid it?! Do some research, and find out just how traumatic the treatments for cervical cancer can be. Screening is not a panacea.

Neither the long-term effectiveness of this vaccine (to prevent cervical cancer) nor its long-term safety have been scientifically established. What we do know, on the other hand, is that mortality rates from cervical cancer in the U.S. are quite low due to effective screening programs.

My objections to the vaccine are based solely on the above facts. I highly resent efforts on the part of the medical establishment to portray me as some unenlightened parent who is refusing to face her daughter's sexuality.

I could not figure out what the wordplay was that made SUGARY the answer to 22D "Oddly, swung fairly sweet," until I was about to ask in here. I took one final look at the clue and it finally clicked that "oddly" didn't mean to anagram one of the words in the clue. Clever! I like that better than the usual way the answer is spelled out across a couple of words in the clue.

This was harder for me that the usual acrostic, but I still enjoyed it. I had to use alphabet runs in a couple of places, but I finally got it, and got the wordplay behind the clues.
